Description: Rim and body sherd of South Ionian pottery little-master cup; glaze fired red-brown; interior: rim reserved save for single line; glazed below; exterior: part of myrtle leaf pattern on rim; handle zone reserved save for line at top; glazed below; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Schlotzhauer little master Ionian Cup type
Curator's comments: Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd, the decorative motif and carinated junction of the rim and body find parallels with his South Ionian little master cups and South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9C. Type 9C cups correspond to Attic Siana, Band, and Gordion cups and find parallels with Hayes' Ionian Cup Type XI (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116). The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Type 5 cups are rare at Naukratis whereas there are numerous examples of Type 9 cups. Both types were common drinking vessels found in Greeks sanctuaries, including the sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus. Hayes suggested a Rhodian origin for these types of cups but this is uncertain (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 114). Schlotzhauer points out that the same myrtle pattern is found on Fikellura style pottery from Miletus and thus suggest a South Ionian or more specifically Milesian origin for the cups (Schlotzhauer 2012, 108-9).
Probably from the same cup as 1888,0601.409 and 1914,0317.11, although the width of some bands is not uniform on the three.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.769) (Phase 3)
